DISCOVER AMERICA

MANY HISTORIC and SCENIC ATTRACTIONS
JUST MINUTES FROM WASHINGTON, D. C.











THIS MAP IS FOLDED TO PROVIDE CONVENIENT
ACCESS TO TOURIST INFORMATION ON MARYLAND'S
FOUR REGIONS INDICATED BELOW.

SPEED LIMITS

Unless otherwise posted are:

Controlled Access Highways
Dual Lane through Highways
Rural Highways
or Residential Area..

Business

SCHOOL BUSSES
When approaching school bus from either direction which has
stopped to receive or discharge pupils, driver must stop and not
proceed until school bus resumes motion. Motorists need not stop
if the bus is on the opposite lane of a dual lane highway or
within the limits of any incorporated city or town with a population
in excess of 25,000.

STOPPING ON HIGHWAYS
When stopping for any purpose, park off the traveled portion of the
highway outside the line of traffic. If your vehicle is disabled, raising
the hood or tying a handkerchief to the door handle or radio
antenna will help call attention to your predicament.
PASSING ZONE
As you drive, observe the center lines on the roadway. Keep in the
righthand lane and do not pass the car ahead when the solid line is
on your side of the road. Posted speed signs, warning and directional
signs are placed along the highway for your guidance and protection.
When approaching another vehicle from either the front or rear, dim
‘your lights. Remember courtesy promotes safety.

Maryland law requires the operator of a vehicle involved in an
accident to stop immediately and remain at the scene of the accident
until the following requirements have been fulfilled:

1) Render assistance to any person injured.

2) Give his name, address and registration number of the vehicle
he is driving and shall upon request exhibit his operator's
license to the person struck or the person attending any
vehicles involved in the collision.

REPORTING ACCIDENTS

The operator of every motor vehicle which is in any manner involved
in an accident within the state in which any person is killed or
injured, or in which damage to the property of any person including
himself, in excess of $150.00 is sustained, shall within 5 days report
the matter in writing to the DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES,
6601 RITCHIE HIGHWAY, N.E., GLEN BURNIE, MARYLAND 21061.
Accident report forms may be obtained from the Department of
Motor Vehicles, State and Local Police Department.











WHEN YOU NEED A FRIEND

The Maryland State Police are highly trained to perform the func- -
tions which will assure the safe and lawful use of the highways of
the State of Maryland. There are over 800 troopers quartered at 28
key locations throughout the State and they are constantly on patrol
in the interest of the motorist. If you need assistance or informa-

tion —

CALL or VISIT

MARYLAND’S MOUNTAINOUS, FOUR-SEASONS RECREATIONAL AREA IS ALSO
THE SITE OF SOME OF AMERICA’S MOST SIGNIFICANT EARLY FRONTIER AND

CIVIL WAR LANDMARKS.

1 DEEP CREEK LAKE, Maryland’s popular all-seasons
mountain playground with 65 miles of shore line pro-
viding ideal swimming and boating during the summer,
and fresh water fishing throughout the year, is the
site of the Wisp Ski Resort. The annual Autumn Glory
Festival is centered here.

2 CASSELMAN RIVER BRIDGE (1813), Grantsville,
a Registered National Historic Landmark, longest single
arch stone bridge in America, part of the Old National
Road.

3 OLD NATIONAL ROAD, begun in 1806, America’s
first federal highway, followed today by U.S. 40 from
Cumberland to the West Virginia border.

4 NATIONAL ROAD TOLL HOUSE, U.S. 40, west of
Cumberland, an original structure of the early 1800’s.

5 CUMBERLAND, known as “The Queen of the
Alleghenies,” is like stepping back in the pages of his-
tory. The Court House stands on the original site of Old
Fort Cumberland, and the log cabin George Washington
used as his western headquarters is located in the
center of the city. On the western edge of the city,
the famous Cumberland Narrows, the east-west gate-
way through the Alleghenies, is a beautiful rocky gorge
rising over 1000 feet above Wills Creek and the high-
way (The Old National Road, U.S. 40).

6 FORT FREDERICK STATE PARK, off 1-70 & Md. 56,
here dominating the Potomac River stands a massive
stone fort built (1756) as a defense against the French
and Indians. On scheduled weekends in summer, the
re-created ‘“Maryland Line,” of Revolutionary War
fame, presents 18th century drills and military crafts.

7 HAGERSTOWN, a modern industrial city in the
Allegheny foothills. Of special interest to visitors is
the Historic Hager House (1739), located in the City
Park, now a museum of frontier life, formerly the
stone fort-home of the city’s founder. The Washington
County Museum of Fine Arts, also in the City Park,
features outstanding exhibits. The artistic skill of 18th
century German stone masons reflected in walls and
buildings contributes to the beauty of the city.

8 ANTIETAM NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD, the site of
a major Civil War conflict, virtually unchanged since
September, 1862, at Sharpsburg, on Md. 65.

9 CRYSTAL GROTTO, a limestone cavern with

jeweled stalactites and stalagmites, commercially
operated off Alt. U.S. 40, near Boonsboro.

The Cumberland Narrows in scenic Western Maryland













Autumn glory in Maryland

10 WASHINGTON MONUMENT (1826), the first
monument erected to George Washington, Alt. U.S. 40,
in State Park near Boonsboro.

11 GATHLAND STATE PARK, site of the famous War
Correspondents Arch, and future site of a Freedom
of the Press memorial, off Alt. U.S. 40 south of
Boonsboro.

12 BRADDOCK HEIGHTS SKI WAY, commercially
operated, popular family ski slope near Frederick, off
Alt. U.S. 40.

13 FREDERICK, is rich in historic heritage and
distinctive architecture of the 18th and 19th centuries.
You may visit the restored home-museum of Barbara
Fritchie, heroine of Whittier's poem, the home of Chief
Justice Roger Brook Taney, and the tomb of Francis
Scott Key, where the flag flies night and day to honor
the author of the Star-Spangled Banner.

14 LILYPONS, the site of Three Springs Fisheries,
world’s largest growers of goldfish and floating plants,
off U.S. 15.

P STRONGHOLD, on Sugar Loaf Mountain, near
Lilypons, a handsome private estate open to the public
for picnics and recreation.

16 NEW MARKET, Maryland’s nationally famous
antique center, off U.S. 40.

17 uTICA COVERED BRIDGE, on US. 15, six miles
north of Frederick on Old Frederick Road, near village
of Utica.

18 CATOCTIN IRON FURNACE where armour plate
for the Ironclad Monitor was made, on U.S. 15, north
of Frederick.

19 OWENS CREEK COVERED BRIDGE, from Thurmont
take Md. 77 (Rocky Ridge Road) east 3 miles to inter-
section with Old Frederick Road, turn right.

20 RODDY ROAD COVERED BRIDGE, on Roddy Road,
1 mile north of Thurmont, off U.S. 15.

21 GROTTO OF LOURDES, first National Catholic
Shrine in America, U.S. 15, Emmitsburg.

22 MOTHER SETON SHRINE at the tomb of the
founder of the American Sisters of Charity, St. Joseph’s
College, Emmitsburg.

ATTRACTIONS Key

Mason and Dixon Line

PENNSYLVANIA







THIS AREA, THE PIEDMONT PLATEAU, IS NOTED FOR
ITS THOROUGHBRED HORSE BREEDING FARMS,
RACE TRACKS, NATIONAL HISTORIC SHRINES AND
RECREATIONAL ATTRACTIONS. HERE IS THE GREAT
CITY OF BALTIMORE, BIRTHPLACE OF THE
STAR-SPANGLED BANNER, ONE OF THE
WORLD’S GREAT PORTS AND CENTER OF
CULTURE, SPORTS AND ENTERTAINMENT.

23 SHRIVER HOMESTEAD & MILL, Union Mills, a
museum of 150 years of American country life, on U.S.
140.

24 WESTMINSTER (U.S. 140), the 150-year old
Carroll County Farm Museum, off Bishop Street, and
“Historical House, with its rare collection of antique
fashion model dolls and Zuber wallpaper, and an
exhibit of the first county-wide RFD in the United
States.

25 INTERNATIONAL GIFT SHOP OF THE CHURCH
WORLD SERVICE MISSION, New Windsor, sells unusual
items from around the world to support its activities.

26 WHITE'S FERRY AQUA CLUB, commercially oper-
ated, recreational and campsite area along the C & 0
Canal on Md. 107 north-west of Washington, D.C.

21 GREAT FALLS OF THE POTOMAC, west of Wash-
ington in Montgomery County, on Md. 189.

28 CLARA BARTON HOUSE, a National Historic
Landmark, in Glen Echo, Montgomery County, home
of the founder and first president of the American
National Red Cross. Contains Clara Barton’s personal
belongings and furnishings of the era. Open daily
1-5 p.m. Closed Mondays and Holidays.

29 CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL NATIONAL PARK,
stretching from Georgetown, (McArthur Bivd.), in Wash-
ington, D.C. into Maryland.

30 ENCHANTED FOREST, commercially operated,
fairy-tale wonderland for children, on U.S. 40 at
Ellicott City. :

3] HAMPTON HOUSE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE,
Towson, the home of a great 18th century Maryland
family, the Ridgleys.

32 BUNKER HILL ROAD COVERED BRIDGE, Hereford
(Baltimore County), Md. 45 north one mile, turn left
and follow road one mile to bridge, over Gunpowder
Falls.

33 AMOS MILL, an 18th century gristmill in Harford
County off Md. 136, on Amos Mill Road.

34 JERICHO COVERED BRIDGE and JERUSALEM
MILLS, one of Maryland's historic. gristmills, U.S. 1,
north through Kingsville to Jerusalem Road.

35 ARMY ORDINANCE MUSEUM, at Aberdeen Proving
Grounds, offer the world’s largest collection of weapons
of war, off U.S. 40,

36 CONOWINGO DAM, controlling the Susquehanna
River, provides fine fishing in either the lake, or
the river below the dam, on U.S. 1.









Carroll County Farm Museum, Westminster









CARROLL




A -

HARFORD

Midshipmen formation of the Naval Academy









T § o



World port of Baltimore.





38 LAUREL RACE COURSE, home of the Washington,
D.C. International and other top horse racing events,
off U.S. 1 at Laurel.

39 UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, College Park, one
of the largest universities in the United States, on
US. 1.

40 BOWIE RACE TRACK, one of Maryland's famous
horse race courses, on Md. 197, off U.S. 50.

41 MARLBORO PARK SPEEDWAY, Upper Marlboro,
features International Championship Sports Car Racing
from April through October, off U.S. 301.













37 BALTIMORE, the National Anthem City, enjoys
a famous historic past. Today, however, it is gaining
new fame for an exciting, modern renaissance, led
by its downtown revitalization program incorporating
a huge Civic Center, a new legitimate theatre —
America’s first in a half century — and a striking
new waterfront for its world port.

The seventh largest city in the United States, Balti-
more is a major manufacturing, medical and science
research and development center. It has a reputation
for fine food and good entertainment, including a
variety’ of national championship professional sports.
Pimlico Race Course, home of the famous Preakness,
is within the city limits.

Downtown Baltimore has been long famed for its
excellent shopping facilities, which include the world
famous Lexington Market in continuous use since 1782.
Modern glass and metal skyscrapers stand next to
ornate stone buildings of the 19th and early 20th
++_centuries. \

Baltimore's attractions include Fort McHenry National
Shrine, where the Star-Spangled Banner flew and in-
spired Francis Scott Key to compose our national
anthem, the Flag House Museum, the Shot Tower, the
Charles - Carroll of Carrollton House, Baltimore and
Ohio Transportation Museum, the Peale Museum
(America’s first museum), the Baltimore Museum of
Art, the Walters Art Gallery, Johns Hopkins Hospital
and University, the Peabody Institute, the Edgar Allan
Poe House, Mount Clare Mansion, the Enoch Pratt
Free Library. At the Maryland Historical Society is
the original manuscript of the “‘Star-Spangled Banner,”
as well as a vast collection of Maryland memorabilia,

including many War of 1812 and Civil War relics.
Visitors, especially those from inland areas, are

4 thrilled at the sight of Baltimore’s immense port
area. At Pier 2, Pratt Street, in the heart of down-
town, lies the oldest ship of the United States Navy,
the Frigate Constellation, built in 1797 — now a
Registered National Historic Landmark. Also in the
port area is McCormick Company, world’s largest spice
processor. There visitors can take an interesting plant
tour.







BALTIMORE

WASHIN

THIS IS A LAND FILLED WITH REMINDERS OF EARLY AMERICAN
HISTORY AND ENGLISH CAVALIER TRADITIONS. IT IS ALSO ONE
OF THE GREATEST PLEASURE BOATING CENTERS ON THE EAST
COAST, AS WELL AS THE HEART OF MARYLAND TOBACCO COUNTRY.

Skipjacks of the Chesapeake Bay's Oyster Sailing fleet











42 FORT WASHINGTON, on the Potomac River, an
impressive reminder of late 18th century warfare off
Md. 210.

43 MARSHALL HALL, commercially operated family
amusement park on the Potomac River, on Md. 227.

44 10BACCO AUCTIONS, at Upper Marlboro, Waysons
Corner, Waldorf, La Plata, and Hughesville. World's
largest loose-leaf tobacco auctions held last of April
through mid July, Monday through Friday 9 a.m. to
noon. TOBACCO CURING BARNS, large wooden build-
ings with vertical louvres rising to the roof to admit
air for tobacco curing, dot the Southern Maryland
countryside.

45 SMALLWOOD’S RETREAT, Smallwood State Park.

Home of General Smallwood, one of Maryland's
Revolutionary War heroes. Open 1:30 - 4:30 Sundays
and holidays. No regular admission time in winter.
Md. 225 west off U.S. 301.

46 PORT TOBACCO, a ghost town, once a flourishing
seaport, the site of Captain John Smith’s famous spring
still flowing there, off U.S. 301 at La Plata.

47 potOMAC RIVER BRIDGE, links Maryland with
Virginia and the South. AQUALAND, commercially
operated recreation area located at the bridge on
U.S. 301, a popular highway to Florida.

48 ST. CLEMENTS ISLAND, first landing in Maryland
(1634) of the Ark and Dove. Md. 242 off Md. 5.

49 PoINT LOOKOUT, site of a Civil War prison
camp for Confederate soldiers, now a state park offer-
ing fishing, swimming, and camping, on Md. 5.

90 sT. MARY’S CITY, the site of the first Maryland
Settlement of 1634, with a replica of the first State
House of 1676. FREEDOM OF RELIGION MONUMENT,
honors the “Act Concerning Religion” passed in 1649
by the Maryland General Assembly, the first legislation
for religious freedom in history, on Md. 5.

91 SOLOMONS ISLAND at Calvert County tip, sur-
rounded by Bay and two-mile wide Patuxent, the
river up which the British sailed to attack Washington
in 1814. THE MARYLAND MARINE BIOLOGICAL LAB-
ORATORY presents an interesting live exhibit of Chesa-
peake Bay marine life.

52 SOTTERLEY, a 1730 tobacco plantation manor
house, open to the public in summer, on Md. 245 in
St. Mary’s County.

53 CLIFFS OF CALVERT, fronting on Chesapeake Bay
in Calvert County, with exposed fossils millions of
years old. Not open to the public.

54 BATTLE CREEK CYPRESS SWAMP, near Bowens,
northernmost of U.S. cypress stands. One of several
in Maryland, Md. 506 off Md. 2.

55 BAY BEACHES, several fine beaches are available
for swimming, boating, fishing, and picnicking.

56 ANNAPOLIS, Maryland's capital since 1649, a
charming waterfront community of national historic
significance, where the American Revolution officially
ended; home of the U.S. Naval Academy and St.
John’s College; a major yachting center and port for
the sailing vessels of the Bay's oyster and fishing
fleet; the site of some of the country’s finest colonial
and federal architecture, in the Registered National
Historic District of the town. THE UNITED STATES
NAVAL ACADEMY, established in Annapolis in 1845,
has the world’s largest dormitory, Bancroft Hall,
housing 4000 future admirals, the Chapel crypt of
John Paul Jones, and the Naval Museum.

97 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE, linking Baltimore and
Southern Maryland with' the Eastern Shore, is the
world’s longest (4.03 miles) all-steel bridge over salt
water, U.S. 301 and U.S. 50.

THE “SHORE,"” AS IT IS CALLED, IS PICTURESQUE TIDEWATER COUNTRY WITH
LUSH FARMS, QUAINT FISHING VILLAGES, MAGNIFICENT COLONIAL ESTATES
AND HISTORIC TOWNS. OCEAN CITY AND ASSATEAGUE NATIONAL SEASHORE

Ocean City's sandy beach offers fun for all

58 ROGERS TAVERN, Perryville, and 18th century
stagecoach station now restored as a museum.

59 PRINCIPIO FURNACE RUINS, established 1719,
produced cannon for the Revolution, and destrpyed
by the British in the War of 1812, on U.S. 40, 4 miles
north of Susquehanna River.

60 GiLPINS BRIDGE, Cecil County, about four miles
north of North East, on Md. 272, over North East
Creek.

61 CHESAPEAKE & DELAWARE CANAL, Chesapeake
City, links Port of Baltimore with Philadelphia and
North Atlantic, site of Pump House and Water Wheel
(1851). Registered National Historic Landmark. U.S.
213.

62 OLD BOHEMIA CHURCH, Warwick, the site of
the first Catholic school in the British colonies, on
Md. 282, off U.S. 213.

63 FREDERICKTOWN, a picturesque, waterside village

-with an old grain warehouse of by-gone days converted
into a restaurant. GEORGETOWN, site of the Kitty
Knight House, now an inn named for Mistress Kitty,
who matched wits with a British admiral and saved
the town in the War of 1812 on U.S. 213.

64 CHESTERTOWN, the site of Washington College
(1782), to which George Washington gave the right
to use his name, on U.S. 213.

65 CENTREVILLE, an 18th century town with its old
Court House and Lawyers Row still in use, and Wright's
Chance, a typical example of an 18th century Eastern
Shore plantation home, now being restored as a
museum. :

66 wyE MILLS, an 18th century country village with
an old school house and Maryland’s official tree, a

"Mr white oak, 450 years old, on Md. 404 off U.S. 50.

67 CHESAPEAKE BAY MARITIME MUSEUM, St
Michael’s, presents an array of Bay relics and memor-
abilia, including several old sailing craft, a lighthouse
and lightship, on Md. 33 off U.S. 50.

68 EASTON, especially appealing to antique seekers,
waterfowl hunters and sport fisherman, on U.S. 50.

;EOMICO\









T





5
é?
m : L Gﬂ' Q
) ocean 09 OXFORD, a waterside village noted for its sailing

ciry craft and the Robert Morris Inn, the family house
‘of the “Financier of the Revolution.” OXFORD-
BELLEVUE FERRY, carrying three cars is the oldest non-

cable ferry in the United States, on Md. 333 off

U.s. 50.

70 LINCHESTER MILL, an ancient water powered
mill, the nation’s oldest (since 1660) industry in con-
tinuous operation, on Md. 318, near Preston.

71 OLD TRINITY CHURCH, the oldest Protestant
church (1674) in use in the country, on Md. 16, 5
miles south of Cambridge.

72 BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, the
fall and winter habitat of the nation’s largest con-
centration of waterfowl, off Md. 355, 9 miles south
of Cambridge. :

73 MASON-DIXON MARKER, one of the boundary
stones, set 200 years ago by the famous surveyors,
Mason and Dixon, to divide Maryland from Penn-
sylvania and Delaware, and establishing the traditional
line between the North and the South off U.S. 50
on Md. 467.

74 SALISBURY, the Eastern Shore’s major commercial
center, the site of the National Indoor Tennis
Championship Tournaments, on U.S. 50 and 13.

75 OCEAN CITY, one of the finest resorts on the
Atlantic Coast, on ten miles of wide, white sandy
beach, with a three-mile boardwalk, and all facilities
and accommodations, Marlin fishing, off Ocean City
and Assateague Island is unexcelled anywhere.

76 ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, wildly beautiful barrier
reef, the home of the famous Chincoteague ponies,
the site of national and state parks being developed
for campers and sport fishermen.

77 SNOW HILL, the site of the Nassawango Iron
Furnace ruins, and the Julia Purnell Museum with its
unusual collection of historic memorabilia, on U.S. 113.

78 PRINCESS ANNE, an 18th century town retaining
much of its original charm, on U.S. 13. Here in Mid-
October, “Olde Princess Anne Days” festival pre-
sented.

79 DEAL ISLAND, typical of many Chesapeake Bay
fishing villages, on Md. 363, off U.S. 13.

80 CRISFIELD, a leading Eastern Shore seafood
center, port for the Smith Island excursion boats, on
Md. 413, off U.S. 13. ‘

81 SMITH ISLAND, ten miles off shore, in Tangier
Sound, a fishing village virtually unchanged since “its
settling 300 years ago. Visited by excursion boats
from Crisfield in spring and summer.

82 REHOBETH PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, the first
Presbyterian church in America (1705), on Md. 667, off
us. 13.

83 POCOMOKE CITY, on the tropical-like Pocomoke
River, noted for its annual National Bass Round-up,
on US. 13.











Maryland’s official highway map is more than a guide to our
highway system. It has been designed to provide you with maximum
assistance in your travels and in making best use of our highways.

Roadside picnic areas, state parks, wildlife preserves and our
many scenic and historic attractions are listed on the highway map.
Whether you are a visitor, or a resident of this great state, you
are invited to take full advantage of all that Maryland has to offer.

Maryland is interested in your comfort, your recreational needs,
and your safety. As you travel, help us keep you safe by observing
our traffic laws and the established rules of courtesy on the road.

5

SPIRO T. AGNEW, Governor



STATE ROADS COMMISSION

Maryland Department of Economic Development, State Office Building,
Annapolis, Maryland 21401, Area Code 301, 268-3371.

DISCOVER AMERICA

MANY HISTORIC and SCENIC ATTRACTIONS
JUST MINUTES FROM WASHINGTON, D. C.











THIS MAP IS FOLDED TO PROVIDE CONVENIENT
ACCESS TO TOURIST INFORMATION ON MARYLAND'S
FOUR REGIONS INDICATED BELOW.

ESTERN

MARYLAND

ENTRAL MARYLAND
OUTHERN MARYLAND
ASTERN SHORE









SPEED LIMITS

Unless otherwise posted are:

Controlled Access Highways
Dual Lane through Highways
Rural Highways
or Residential Area..

Business

SCHOOL BUSSES
When approaching school bus from either direction which has
stopped to receive or discharge pupils, driver must stop and not
proceed until school bus resumes motion. Motorists need not stop
if the bus is on the opposite lane of a dual lane highway or
within the limits of any incorporated city or town with a population
in excess of 25,000.

STOPPING ON HIGHWAYS
When stopping for any purpose, park off the traveled portion of the
highway outside the line of traffic. If your vehicle is disabled, raising
the hood or tying a handkerchief to the door handle or radio
antenna will help call attention to your predicament.
PASSING ZONE
As you drive, observe the center lines on the roadway. Keep in the
righthand lane and do not pass the car ahead when the solid line is
on your side of the road. Posted speed signs, warning and directional
signs are placed along the highway for your guidance and protection.
When approaching another vehicle from either the front or rear, dim
‘your lights. Remember courtesy promotes safety.

Maryland law requires the operator of a vehicle involved in an
accident to stop immediately and remain at the scene of the accident
until the following requirements have been fulfilled:

1) Render assistance to any person injured.

2) Give his name, address and registration number of the vehicle
he is driving and shall upon request exhibit his operator's
license to the person struck or the person attending any
vehicles involved in the collision.

REPORTING ACCIDENTS

The operator of every motor vehicle which is in any manner involved
in an accident within the state in which any person is killed or
injured, or in which damage to the property of any person including
himself, in excess of $150.00 is sustained, shall within 5 days report
the matter in writing to the DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES,
6601 RITCHIE HIGHWAY, N.E., GLEN BURNIE, MARYLAND 21061.
Accident report forms may be obtained from the Department of
Motor Vehicles, State and Local Police Department.











WHEN YOU NEED A FRIEND

The Maryland State Police are highly trained to perform the func- -
tions which will assure the safe and lawful use of the highways of
the State of Maryland. There are over 800 troopers quartered at 28
key locations throughout the State and they are constantly on patrol
in the interest of the motorist. If you need assistance or informa-

tion —

CALL or VISIT

4

MARYLAND’S MOUNTAINOUS, FOUR-SEASONS RECREATIONAL AREA IS ALSO
THE SITE OF SOME OF AMERICA’S MOST SIGNIFICANT EARLY FRONTIER AND

CIVIL WAR LANDMARKS.

1 DEEP CREEK LAKE, Maryland’s popular all-seasons
mountain playground with 65 miles of shore line pro-
viding ideal swimming and boating during the summer,
and fresh water fishing throughout the year, is the
site of the Wisp Ski Resort. The annual Autumn Glory
Festival is centered here.

2 CASSELMAN RIVER BRIDGE (1813), Grantsville,
a Registered National Historic Landmark, longest single
arch stone bridge in America, part of the Old National
Road.

3 OLD NATIONAL ROAD, begun in 1806, America’s
first federal highway, followed today by U.S. 40 from
Cumberland to the West Virginia border.

4 NATIONAL ROAD TOLL HOUSE, U.S. 40, west of
Cumberland, an original structure of the early 1800’s.

5 CUMBERLAND, known as “The Queen of the
Alleghenies,” is like stepping back in the pages of his-
tory. The Court House stands on the original site of Old
Fort Cumberland, and the log cabin George Washington
used as his western headquarters is located in the
center of the city. On the western edge of the city,
the famous Cumberland Narrows, the east-west gate-
way through the Alleghenies, is a beautiful rocky gorge
rising over 1000 feet above Wills Creek and the high-
way (The Old National Road, U.S. 40).

6 FORT FREDERICK STATE PARK, off 1-70 & Md. 56,
here dominating the Potomac River stands a massive
stone fort built (1756) as a defense against the French
and Indians. On scheduled weekends in summer, the
re-created ‘“Maryland Line,” of Revolutionary War
fame, presents 18th century drills and military crafts.

7 HAGERSTOWN, a modern industrial city in the
Allegheny foothills. Of special interest to visitors is
the Historic Hager House (1739), located in the City
Park, now a museum of frontier life, formerly the
stone fort-home of the city’s founder. The Washington
County Museum of Fine Arts, also in the City Park,
features outstanding exhibits. The artistic skill of 18th
century German stone masons reflected in walls and
buildings contributes to the beauty of the city.

8 ANTIETAM NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD, the site of
a major Civil War conflict, virtually unchanged since
September, 1862, at Sharpsburg, on Md. 65.

9 CRYSTAL GROTTO, a limestone cavern with

jeweled stalactites and stalagmites, commercially
operated off Alt. U.S. 40, near Boonsboro.

The Cumberland Narrows in scenic Western Maryland













Autumn glory in Maryland

10 WASHINGTON MONUMENT (1826), the first
monument erected to George Washington, Alt. U.S. 40,
in State Park near Boonsboro.

11 GATHLAND STATE PARK, site of the famous War
Correspondents Arch, and future site of a Freedom
of the Press memorial, off Alt. U.S. 40 south of
Boonsboro.

12 BRADDOCK HEIGHTS SKI WAY, commercially
operated, popular family ski slope near Frederick, off
Alt. U.S. 40.

13 FREDERICK, is rich in historic heritage and
distinctive architecture of the 18th and 19th centuries.
You may visit the restored home-museum of Barbara
Fritchie, heroine of Whittier's poem, the home of Chief
Justice Roger Brook Taney, and the tomb of Francis
Scott Key, where the flag flies night and day to honor
the author of the Star-Spangled Banner.

14 LILYPONS, the site of Three Springs Fisheries,
world’s largest growers of goldfish and floating plants,
off U.S. 15.

P STRONGHOLD, on Sugar Loaf Mountain, near
Lilypons, a handsome private estate open to the public
for picnics and recreation.

16 NEW MARKET, Maryland’s nationally famous
antique center, off U.S. 40.

17 uTICA COVERED BRIDGE, on US. 15, six miles
north of Frederick on Old Frederick Road, near village
of Utica.

18 CATOCTIN IRON FURNACE where armour plate
for the Ironclad Monitor was made, on U.S. 15, north
of Frederick.

19 OWENS CREEK COVERED BRIDGE, from Thurmont
take Md. 77 (Rocky Ridge Road) east 3 miles to inter-
section with Old Frederick Road, turn right.

20 RODDY ROAD COVERED BRIDGE, on Roddy Road,
1 mile north of Thurmont, off U.S. 15.

21 GROTTO OF LOURDES, first National Catholic
Shrine in America, U.S. 15, Emmitsburg.

22 MOTHER SETON SHRINE at the tomb of the
founder of the American Sisters of Charity, St. Joseph’s
College, Emmitsburg.

Mason and Dixon Line

PENNSYLVANIA







THIS AREA, THE PIEDMONT PLATEAU, IS NOTED FOR
ITS THOROUGHBRED HORSE BREEDING FARMS,
RACE TRACKS, NATIONAL HISTORIC SHRINES AND
RECREATIONAL ATTRACTIONS. HERE IS THE GREAT
CITY OF BALTIMORE, BIRTHPLACE OF THE
STAR-SPANGLED BANNER, ONE OF THE
WORLD’S GREAT PORTS AND CENTER OF
CULTURE, SPORTS AND ENTERTAINMENT.

23 SHRIVER HOMESTEAD & MILL, Union Mills, a
museum of 150 years of American country life, on U.S.
140.

24 WESTMINSTER (U.S. 140), the 150-year old
Carroll County Farm Museum, off Bishop Street, and
“Historical House, with its rare collection of antique
fashion model dolls and Zuber wallpaper, and an
exhibit of the first county-wide RFD in the United
States.

25 INTERNATIONAL GIFT SHOP OF THE CHURCH
WORLD SERVICE MISSION, New Windsor, sells unusual
items from around the world to support its activities.

26 WHITE'S FERRY AQUA CLUB, commercially oper-
ated, recreational and campsite area along the C & 0
Canal on Md. 107 north-west of Washington, D.C.

21 GREAT FALLS OF THE POTOMAC, west of Wash-
ington in Montgomery County, on Md. 189.

28 CLARA BARTON HOUSE, a National Historic
Landmark, in Glen Echo, Montgomery County, home
of the founder and first president of the American
National Red Cross. Contains Clara Barton’s personal
belongings and furnishings of the era. Open daily
1-5 p.m. Closed Mondays and Holidays.

29 CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL NATIONAL PARK,
stretching from Georgetown, (McArthur Bivd.), in Wash-
ington, D.C. into Maryland.

30 ENCHANTED FOREST, commercially operated,
fairy-tale wonderland for children, on U.S. 40 at
Ellicott City. :

3] HAMPTON HOUSE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE,
Towson, the home of a great 18th century Maryland
family, the Ridgleys.

32 BUNKER HILL ROAD COVERED BRIDGE, Hereford
(Baltimore County), Md. 45 north one mile, turn left
and follow road one mile to bridge, over Gunpowder
Falls.

33 AMOS MILL, an 18th century gristmill in Harford
County off Md. 136, on Amos Mill Road.

34 JERICHO COVERED BRIDGE and JERUSALEM
MILLS, one of Maryland's historic. gristmills, U.S. 1,
north through Kingsville to Jerusalem Road.

35 ARMY ORDINANCE MUSEUM, at Aberdeen Proving
Grounds, offer the world’s largest collection of weapons
of war, off U.S. 40,

36 CONOWINGO DAM, controlling the Susquehanna
River, provides fine fishing in either the lake, or
the river below the dam, on U.S. 1.









Carroll County Farm Museum, Westminster









CARROLL




A -

HARFORD

8
Q BALTI O‘RxE-






BEL AIR











Midshipmen formation of the Naval Academy









T § o



World port of Baltimore.





38 LAUREL RACE COURSE, home of the Washington,
D.C. International and other top horse racing events,
off U.S. 1 at Laurel.

39 UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, College Park, one
of the largest universities in the United States, on
US. 1.

40 BOWIE RACE TRACK, one of Maryland's famous
horse race courses, on Md. 197, off U.S. 50.

41 MARLBORO PARK SPEEDWAY, Upper Marlboro,
features International Championship Sports Car Racing
from April through October, off U.S. 301.













37 BALTIMORE, the National Anthem City, enjoys
a famous historic past. Today, however, it is gaining
new fame for an exciting, modern renaissance, led
by its downtown revitalization program incorporating
a huge Civic Center, a new legitimate theatre —
America’s first in a half century — and a striking
new waterfront for its world port.

The seventh largest city in the United States, Balti-
more is a major manufacturing, medical and science
research and development center. It has a reputation
for fine food and good entertainment, including a
variety’ of national championship professional sports.
Pimlico Race Course, home of the famous Preakness,
is within the city limits.

Downtown Baltimore has been long famed for its
excellent shopping facilities, which include the world
famous Lexington Market in continuous use since 1782.
Modern glass and metal skyscrapers stand next to
ornate stone buildings of the 19th and early 20th
++_centuries. \

Baltimore's attractions include Fort McHenry National
Shrine, where the Star-Spangled Banner flew and in-
spired Francis Scott Key to compose our national
anthem, the Flag House Museum, the Shot Tower, the
Charles - Carroll of Carrollton House, Baltimore and
Ohio Transportation Museum, the Peale Museum
(America’s first museum), the Baltimore Museum of
Art, the Walters Art Gallery, Johns Hopkins Hospital
and University, the Peabody Institute, the Edgar Allan
Poe House, Mount Clare Mansion, the Enoch Pratt
Free Library. At the Maryland Historical Society is
the original manuscript of the “‘Star-Spangled Banner,”
as well as a vast collection of Maryland memorabilia,

including many War of 1812 and Civil War relics.
Visitors, especially those from inland areas, are

4 thrilled at the sight of Baltimore’s immense port
area. At Pier 2, Pratt Street, in the heart of down-
town, lies the oldest ship of the United States Navy,
the Frigate Constellation, built in 1797 — now a
Registered National Historic Landmark. Also in the
port area is McCormick Company, world’s largest spice
processor. There visitors can take an interesting plant
tour.







BALTIMORE

WASHIN

THIS IS A LAND FILLED WITH REMINDERS OF EARLY AMERICAN
HISTORY AND ENGLISH CAVALIER TRADITIONS. IT IS ALSO ONE
OF THE GREATEST PLEASURE BOATING CENTERS ON THE EAST
COAST, AS WELL AS THE HEART OF MARYLAND TOBACCO COUNTRY.

Skipjacks of the Chesapeake Bay's Oyster Sailing fleet











42 FORT WASHINGTON, on the Potomac River, an
impressive reminder of late 18th century warfare off
Md. 210.

43 MARSHALL HALL, commercially operated family
amusement park on the Potomac River, on Md. 227.

44 10BACCO AUCTIONS, at Upper Marlboro, Waysons
Corner, Waldorf, La Plata, and Hughesville. World's
largest loose-leaf tobacco auctions held last of April
through mid July, Monday through Friday 9 a.m. to
noon. TOBACCO CURING BARNS, large wooden build-
ings with vertical louvres rising to the roof to admit
air for tobacco curing, dot the Southern Maryland
countryside.

45 SMALLWOOD’S RETREAT, Smallwood State Park.

Home of General Smallwood, one of Maryland's
Revolutionary War heroes. Open 1:30 - 4:30 Sundays
and holidays. No regular admission time in winter.
Md. 225 west off U.S. 301.

46 PORT TOBACCO, a ghost town, once a flourishing
seaport, the site of Captain John Smith’s famous spring
still flowing there, off U.S. 301 at La Plata.

47 potOMAC RIVER BRIDGE, links Maryland with
Virginia and the South. AQUALAND, commercially
operated recreation area located at the bridge on
U.S. 301, a popular highway to Florida.

48 ST. CLEMENTS ISLAND, first landing in Maryland
(1634) of the Ark and Dove. Md. 242 off Md. 5.

49 PoINT LOOKOUT, site of a Civil War prison
camp for Confederate soldiers, now a state park offer-
ing fishing, swimming, and camping, on Md. 5.

90 sT. MARY’S CITY, the site of the first Maryland
Settlement of 1634, with a replica of the first State
House of 1676. FREEDOM OF RELIGION MONUMENT,
honors the “Act Concerning Religion” passed in 1649
by the Maryland General Assembly, the first legislation
for religious freedom in history, on Md. 5.

91 SOLOMONS ISLAND at Calvert County tip, sur-
rounded by Bay and two-mile wide Patuxent, the
river up which the British sailed to attack Washington
in 1814. THE MARYLAND MARINE BIOLOGICAL LAB-
ORATORY presents an interesting live exhibit of Chesa-
peake Bay marine life.

52 SOTTERLEY, a 1730 tobacco plantation manor
house, open to the public in summer, on Md. 245 in
St. Mary’s County.

53 CLIFFS OF CALVERT, fronting on Chesapeake Bay
in Calvert County, with exposed fossils millions of
years old. Not open to the public.

54 BATTLE CREEK CYPRESS SWAMP, near Bowens,
northernmost of U.S. cypress stands. One of several
in Maryland, Md. 506 off Md. 2.

55 BAY BEACHES, several fine beaches are available
for swimming, boating, fishing, and picnicking.

56 ANNAPOLIS, Maryland's capital since 1649, a
charming waterfront community of national historic
significance, where the American Revolution officially
ended; home of the U.S. Naval Academy and St.
John’s College; a major yachting center and port for
the sailing vessels of the Bay's oyster and fishing
fleet; the site of some of the country’s finest colonial
and federal architecture, in the Registered National
Historic District of the town. THE UNITED STATES
NAVAL ACADEMY, established in Annapolis in 1845,
has the world’s largest dormitory, Bancroft Hall,
housing 4000 future admirals, the Chapel crypt of
John Paul Jones, and the Naval Museum.

97 CHESAPEAKE BAY BRIDGE, linking Baltimore and
Southern Maryland with' the Eastern Shore, is the
world’s longest (4.03 miles) all-steel bridge over salt
water, U.S. 301 and U.S. 50.

House (1676), St



S DG )]


















THE “SHORE,"” AS IT IS CALLED, IS PICTURESQUE TIDEWATER COUNTRY WITH
LUSH FARMS, QUAINT FISHING VILLAGES, MAGNIFICENT COLONIAL ESTATES
AND HISTORIC TOWNS. OCEAN CITY AND ASSATEAGUE NATIONAL SEASHORE

Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, St. Michael’s





Ocean City's sandy beach offers fun for all







CAMBRIDGE





DELAWARE






SALISBURY

‘39

PRINCESS SNOW
ANNE HILL

424





42)4

58 ROGERS TAVERN, Perryville, and 18th century
stagecoach station now restored as a museum.

59 PRINCIPIO FURNACE RUINS, established 1719,
produced cannon for the Revolution, and destrpyed
by the British in the War of 1812, on U.S. 40, 4 miles
north of Susquehanna River.

60 GiLPINS BRIDGE, Cecil County, about four miles
north of North East, on Md. 272, over North East
Creek.

61 CHESAPEAKE & DELAWARE CANAL, Chesapeake
City, links Port of Baltimore with Philadelphia and
North Atlantic, site of Pump House and Water Wheel
(1851). Registered National Historic Landmark. U.S.
213.

62 OLD BOHEMIA CHURCH, Warwick, the site of
the first Catholic school in the British colonies, on
Md. 282, off U.S. 213.

63 FREDERICKTOWN, a picturesque, waterside village

-with an old grain warehouse of by-gone days converted
into a restaurant. GEORGETOWN, site of the Kitty
Knight House, now an inn named for Mistress Kitty,
who matched wits with a British admiral and saved
the town in the War of 1812 on U.S. 213.

64 CHESTERTOWN, the site of Washington College
(1782), to which George Washington gave the right
to use his name, on U.S. 213.

65 CENTREVILLE, an 18th century town with its old
Court House and Lawyers Row still in use, and Wright's
Chance, a typical example of an 18th century Eastern
Shore plantation home, now being restored as a
museum. :

66 wyE MILLS, an 18th century country village with
an old school house and Maryland’s official tree, a

"Mr white oak, 450 years old, on Md. 404 off U.S. 50.

67 CHESAPEAKE BAY MARITIME MUSEUM, St
Michael’s, presents an array of Bay relics and memor-
abilia, including several old sailing craft, a lighthouse
and lightship, on Md. 33 off U.S. 50.

68 EASTON, especially appealing to antique seekers,
waterfowl hunters and sport fisherman, on U.S. 50.

;EOMICO\









T





5
é?
m : L Gﬂ' Q
) ocean 09 OXFORD, a waterside village noted for its sailing

ciry craft and the Robert Morris Inn, the family house
‘of the “Financier of the Revolution.” OXFORD-
BELLEVUE FERRY, carrying three cars is the oldest non-

cable ferry in the United States, on Md. 333 off

U.s. 50.

70 LINCHESTER MILL, an ancient water powered
mill, the nation’s oldest (since 1660) industry in con-
tinuous operation, on Md. 318, near Preston.

71 OLD TRINITY CHURCH, the oldest Protestant
church (1674) in use in the country, on Md. 16, 5
miles south of Cambridge.

72 BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, the
fall and winter habitat of the nation’s largest con-
centration of waterfowl, off Md. 355, 9 miles south
of Cambridge. :

73 MASON-DIXON MARKER, one of the boundary
stones, set 200 years ago by the famous surveyors,
Mason and Dixon, to divide Maryland from Penn-
sylvania and Delaware, and establishing the traditional
line between the North and the South off U.S. 50
on Md. 467.

74 SALISBURY, the Eastern Shore’s major commercial
center, the site of the National Indoor Tennis
Championship Tournaments, on U.S. 50 and 13.

75 OCEAN CITY, one of the finest resorts on the
Atlantic Coast, on ten miles of wide, white sandy
beach, with a three-mile boardwalk, and all facilities
and accommodations, Marlin fishing, off Ocean City
and Assateague Island is unexcelled anywhere.

76 ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, wildly beautiful barrier
reef, the home of the famous Chincoteague ponies,
the site of national and state parks being developed
for campers and sport fishermen.

77 SNOW HILL, the site of the Nassawango Iron
Furnace ruins, and the Julia Purnell Museum with its
unusual collection of historic memorabilia, on U.S. 113.

78 PRINCESS ANNE, an 18th century town retaining
much of its original charm, on U.S. 13. Here in Mid-
October, “Olde Princess Anne Days” festival pre-
sented.

79 DEAL ISLAND, typical of many Chesapeake Bay
fishing villages, on Md. 363, off U.S. 13.

80 CRISFIELD, a leading Eastern Shore seafood
center, port for the Smith Island excursion boats, on
Md. 413, off U.S. 13. ‘

81 SMITH ISLAND, ten miles off shore, in Tangier
Sound, a fishing village virtually unchanged since “its
settling 300 years ago. Visited by excursion boats
from Crisfield in spring and summer.

82 REHOBETH PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, the first
Presbyterian church in America (1705), on Md. 667, off
us. 13.

83 POCOMOKE CITY, on the tropical-like Pocomoke
River, noted for its annual National Bass Round-up,
on US. 13.











Maryland’s official highway map is more than a guide to our
highway system. It has been designed to provide you with maximum
assistance in your travels and in making best use of our highways.

Roadside picnic areas, state parks, wildlife preserves and our
many scenic and historic attractions are listed on the highway map.
Whether you are a visitor, or a resident of this great state, you
are invited to take full advantage of all that Maryland has to offer.

Maryland is interested in your comfort, your recreational needs,
and your safety. As you travel, help us keep you safe by observing
our traffic laws and the established rules of courtesy on the road.

5

SPIRO T. AGNEW, Governor
